title: Nvidia Has Two New RTX Pro GPUs Ready to Go and They Could Be Great For Lower Power Systems
description: The compact Blackwell cards are small-form-factor friendly.
content:
Nvidia isn’t quite done with its RTX Pro Blackwell workstation line. The company has two low-power GPUs waiting in the wings, and although there isn’t an official launch date yet, Nvidia indicated that they’ll be out before the end of the year. Both GPUs have a Thermal Design Power (TDP) max of 70W, making them easily the most low-power RTX Pros in the series. For comparison, the next step up, which is the RTX Pro 4000, has a 140W TDP rating.

The two upcoming GPUs are the Nvidia RTX Pro 4000 SFF and the RTX Pro 2000, both of which have compact card designs. They are just 2.7” high and 6.6” long, though the RTX Pro 2000 has a full height bracket. Neither of these GPUs should go in a gaming PC, but as Videocardz points out, they could end up in a home theater PC or a home SFF workstation. They’ll certainly find spots in workstations for business settings, as well.

The RTX Pro 4000 SFF GPU sports 20GB of GDDR6 memory with error correction code (ECC). That's 4GB less memory than on the full-sized RTX Pro 4000, and 12 GB less than the RTX 5090 (The Pro 4000 also has GDDR7 memory). But the SFF and full-sized versions both have the Nvidia Blackwell GB203 die and 8960 CUDA cores. At this point, the RTX Pro 4000 SFF is the only GPU in the series to run GDDR6 memory; the rest all run GDDR7.

As for the RTX Pro 2000, it has just 16GB of GDDR7 memory with ECC, at a 128-bit memory interface (to the RTX Pro 4000 SFF’s 160-bit). It’s understandably underpowered compared to its SFF cousin, at 545 AI TOPS to the SFF’s 770 AI TOPS.

It’s worth noting that the compactness of the cards is only in their height; each of them eats up two bracket slots at the back of your workstation. Each card has a PCIe 5.0 x8 interface and neither have external power connectors, thanks to their low power requirements.

Pricing is still a question mark for both GPUs, but expect them to be pricier than consumer cards. At the top of the RTX Pro series sits the RTX Pro 6000 Workstation, which debuted above $8,000 and has stayed in that range. It’s more powerful than Nvidia’s consumer flagship, the RTX 5090, but it’s not meant for gaming. Of course, that didn’t stop an overclocker from putting one in his PC and pulling some eye-popping performance from it.

But with the RTX 5090 going for $2,400-$3,000, the RTX 5090 is a far better deal for gamers – and that might be the only time soon that we refer to the 5090’s price as a deal.

keywords.name: its RTX Pro Blackwell workstation line

summary: Nigments have revealed two new low-power GPUs, the Nvidia RTX Pro 4000 SFF and the RTX Pro 2000, which are expected to be released before the end of the year. The new GPUs, which have a maximum 70W TDP rating and compact card designs, could be ideal for lower power systems such as home theater PCs or a home SFF workstation. The RTX Pro 500 and the RT Pro 2000 are compact and could be used in workstations for business purposes, but may not be suited for gaming. The only GPU in the series to run GDDR6 memory is the RTX PRO 4000 Sff, which sports 20GB of memory with error correction code (ECC), while the RTX 2000 has only 16GB of GDDR7 memory with ECC at a 128-bit memory interface. Pricing remains a mystery, but expect them to be pricier than consumer cards.
shortSummary: Nvidia is launching two low-power RTX Pro Blackwell GPUs, the SFF and RTX Pro 2000, with TDPs of 70W and GDDR6 memory respectively.
argos_summary: Nvidia is set to release two low-power GPUs in its RTX Pro Blackwell workstation line before the end of the year: the RTX Pro 4000 SFF and the RTX Pro 2000. Both GPUs feature compact designs and have a maximum Thermal Design Power (TDP) of 70W, making them suitable for home theater PCs and business workstations. The RTX Pro 4000 SFF offers 20GB of GDDR6 memory, while the RTX Pro 2000 has 16GB of GDDR7 memory, with pricing expected to be higher than consumer cards.
